revision.comment: Reverted 2 edits by [[Special:Contributions/50.235.102.246|50.235.102.246]] ([[User talk:50.235.102.246|talk]]) to last revision by Colonies Chris. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
Before the [[Athenian democracy]], the [[tyrant]]s, and the [[Archon]]s, the [[city-state]] of '''[[Athens]] was ruled by [[monarch|kings]]'''. Most of these are probably [[mythology|myth]]ical or only semi-historical. ==Earliest kings== These three kings were supposed to have ruled before the [[Ancient Greek flood myths|flood of Deucalion]]. {| border="0" width=777px ! King !! Comments |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" |width=222px|[[Periphas (Attic king)|Periphas]] || Turned into an eagle by [[Zeus]] |- | [[Ogyges]]King of Agea, not Athens; The name of Ogyges is also connected with Attic mythology, for in Attica too an Ogygian flood is mentioned, and he is described as the father of the Attic hero [[Eleusis (mythology)|Eleusis]] ([[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Paus.+1.38.7 1.38.7])A Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology: Oarses-Zygia. Edited by William Smith. [https://books.google.com/books?id=f-5WAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA20 Pg 20] ||King of the [[Ectenes]]or Hectenes who were the earliest inhabitants of [[Boeotia]] |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" | [[Actaeus]] ||Father of [[Agraulus]], and father-in-law to Cecrops |} ==Erechtheid dynasty== The early Athenian tradition, followed by the 3rd century BC [[Parian Chronicle]], made Cecrops, a mythical half-man half-serpent, the first king of Athens.Harding, pp. 20–22; Gantz, p. 234. The dates for the following kings were conjectured centuries later, by historians of the [[Hellenistic era]] who tried to backdate events by cross-referencing earlier sources such as the Parian Chronicle. Tradition says that King Menestheus took part in the [[Trojan War]]. The following list follows that of 1st Century BC [[Castor of Rhodes]] ([[Fragmente der griechischen Historiker|''FGrHist'']] 250), with Castor's dates given in modern terms.Harding, p. 14. {| border="0" width=777px ! Reign !! King !! Comments |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" |width=111px| 1556–1506 BC || [[Cecrops I]] || |- || 1506–1497 BC || [[Cranaus]] || |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" || 1497–1487 BC || [[Amphictyon]] || |- || 1487–1437 BC || [[Erichthonius of Athens|Erichthonius]] || |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" || 1437–1397 BC || [[Pandion I]] || |- || 1397–1347 BC || [[Erechtheus]] || |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" || 1347–1307 BC || [[Cecrops II]] || Omitted in [[Heraclides Lembus|Heraclides']] epitome of [[Aristotle]]'s ''[[Constitution of the Athenians (Aristotle)|Constitution of the Athenians]]''Gantz, p. 235. |- || 1307–1282 BC || [[Pandion II]] || |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" || 1282–1234 BC || [[Aegeus]] || Construction of Trojan Walls by [[Poseidon]], [[Apollo]] and the mortal [[Aeacus]] (c. 1282 BC) |- || 1234–1205 BC || [[Theseus]] || |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" || 1205–1183 BC || [[Menestheus]] || [[Trojan War]] and the [[Trojan War#The Sack of Troy|Sack of Troy]]See also [[Iliupersis]] (c. 1183 BC)[[Troy VII]]a destruction layer at c. 1190 BC |- || 1183–1150 BC || [[Demophon (King of Athens)|Demophon]] || |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" || 1150–1136 BC || [[Oxyntes]] || |- || 1136–1135 BC || [[Apheidas]] || |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" || 1135–1127 BC || [[Thymoetes]] || |}
{{see also|Autochthon (ancient Greece)|Mythical chronology of Greece}} [[File:Royal House of Athens Genealogical Chart.png|thumb|center|1000px|Mythological Royal House of Athens]] ==Melanthid dynasty== Melanthus having been driven from his kingdom in [[Pylos]] came to Athens where Thymoestes resigned the crown to him. Codrus, the last king, repelled the [[Dorian Invasion]] of [[Attica]]. {| border="0" width=777px ! Reign !! King !! Comments |-bgcolor="#cdcdcd" |width=111px|1126–1089 BC ||[[Melanthus]] || |- ||1089–1068 BC ||[[Codrus]] || |} After Codrus's death, his sons Medon and Acastus either reigned as kings, or became hereditary [[archons]].Pausanias's Description of Greece – Volume 3 – [https://books.google.com/books?id=LjNPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA64 Page 64]. (cf. ''The successors of Codrus were Medon (son of Codrus), Acastus (son of Medon) [...]'')Aristotle, ''[[Constitution of the Athenians (Aristotle)|Constitution of the Athenians]]'' §3. In 753 BC the hereditary archonship was replaced by a non-hereditary system (see [[Archons of Athens]]). {{see also|Neleides}} == Notes == {{reflist}} ==References== {{refbegin}} * Gantz, Timothy, ''Early Greek Myth: A Guide to Literary and Artistic Sources'', Johns Hopkins University Press, 1996, Two volumes: {{ISBN|978-0801853609}} (Vol. 1), {{ISBN|978-0801853623}} (Vol. 2). * Harding, Phillip, ''The Story of Athens: The Fragments of the Local Chronicles of Attika'', Routledge, 2007. {{ISBN|9781134304479}}. * [[Felix Jacoby|Jacoby, Felix]], "Die Attische Königsliste", ''[[Klio (journal)|Klio]]'' 3 (1902), 406–439. {{refend}} {{Ancient Greece topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kings of Athens}} [[Category:Kings of Athens| ]] [[Category:Lists of monarchs|Athens]] [[Category:Ancient Greek titles]] [[Category:Mycenaean Greece]] [[Category:Greece history-related lists|Athens, Kings]] [[Category:Athens-related lists]] [[Category:16th-century BC establishments]]

page.title: List of the largest landowners of Norway

revision.comment: /* Notes and references */minor fixes
revision.text:
'''List of big landowners in Norway''' includes persons as well as private and public companies owning at least {{convert|100|km2|sp=us}} of land in [[Norway]]. The [[Government of Norway]] is, directly and indirectly, by far the largest landowner in the Kingdom. State-owned land is managed by [[Statskog]], while a large portion was spun off to the [[Finnmark Estate]]. In [[Svalbard]], the land is owned directly by the [[Minister of Trade and Industry (Norway)|Minister of Trade and Industry]] as well as by several mining companies. The largest private owner on the mainland is [[Meraker Brug]], which is owned by the Astrup family. Several larger landowners are [[commons]]{{cite web |url=http://www.umb.no/statisk/studier-ilp/master_irene_runningen.pdf |last=Runningen |first=Irene |title=Almenningsretten i et dynamisk samfunn |page=107 |accessdate=21 April 2012 |year=2005}} ({{lang-no|allmenning}}) and [[municipalities of Norway|municipalities]]. ==List== The following is a list of all owners of minimum {{convert|100|km2|sp=us}} of land in Norway. It lists the name of the owner, the location in which the owning institution is registered, the area of land, the ultimate owner of the land, and the owner's sector. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |+ List of the largest landowners of Norway |- !scope="col" | Owner !scope="col" | Based in !scope="col" | Area
(km2) !scope="col" | Area

utmarkseiendommer |publisher=[[Government.no]] |accessdate=21 April 2012}} |- | [[Ministry of Trade and Industry (Norway)|Ministry of Trade and Industry]]{{#tag:ref|The ministry owns 95.2% of Svalbard {{about|the Mars orbiter||Maven (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017| }} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Mars Atmosphere and Volatile Evolution | image = MAVEN spacecraft model.png | image_caption = Artist's rendering of the ''MAVEN'' spacecraft bus | mission_type = Mars atmospheric research |operator = [[NASA]] | website = [http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/maven/main/index.html NASA MAVEN] | COSPAR_ID = 2013-063A | SATCAT = 39378 | mission_duration = 1 Earth year.
Science phase extended through September 2016.
Additional 6 years as telecomm relay (planned). | manufacturer = [[Lockheed Martin Space Systems|Lockheed Martin]]
[[University of Colorado Boulder|CU-Boulder]]
[[University of California, Berkeley|Berkeley]]
[[NASA]] [[Goddard Space Flight Center|GSFC]] | dry_mass = {{convert|809|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | launch_mass = {{convert|2454|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | payload_mass = {{convert|65|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | dimensions = | power = 1,135 watts[http://mars.jpl.nasa.gov/files/resources/MAVENPresentation2013.pdf 'MAVEN' Mission PowerPoint] | launch_date = November 18, 2013, 18:28 UTC | launch_rocket = [[Atlas V]] 401 AV-038 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 41|SLC-41]] | launch_contractor = [[United Launch Alliance]] | last_contact = | decay_date = | orbit_epoch = Planned | orbit_reference = [[Areocentric orbit|Areocentric]] (Mars) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|150|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|6200|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_inclination = 75 degrees | orbit_semimajor = | orbit_eccentricity = | orbit_period = 4.5 hours | apsis = areion |interplanetary = {{Infobox spaceflight/IP |type = orbiter |object = [[Mars]] |orbits = |arrival_date = September 22, 2014, 02:24 UTC
[[Timekeeping on Mars|MSD]] 50025 08:07 [[Airy Mean Time|AMT]] }} | instruments = | insignia = MAVEN Mission Logo.png | insignia_size = 140px | programme = '''[[Mars Scout Program]]''' | previous_mission = ''[[Phoenix (spacecraft)|Phoenix]]'' | next_mission = }} '''Mars Atmosphere and Volatile EvolutioN''' ('''MAVEN'''){{cite web|title=MAVEN Mission Overview |url=https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/maven/overview/index.html |website=MAVEN |publisher=[[NASA]] |accessdate=9 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131021910/https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/maven/overview/index.html |archivedate=January 31, 2017 |location=Washington, DC |date=2015-07-30 |quote=The Mars Atmosphere and Volatile EvolutioN (MAVEN) mission is part of NASA's Mars Scout program, funded by NASA Headquarters. |deadurl=yes |df= }} mission was developed by [[NASA]] to study the [[atmosphere of Mars|Martian atmosphere]] while orbiting [[Mars]]. Mission goals include determining how the planet's [[atmosphere of Mars|atmosphere]] and [[Water on Mars|water]], presumed to have once been substantial, were lost over time.{{cite web |last=Brown |first=Dwayne |last2=Neal-Jones |first2=Nancy |last3=Zubritsky |first3=Elizabeth |title=NASA's Newest Mars Mission Spacecraft Enters Orbit around Red Planet |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?release=2014-318 |date=September 21, 2014 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=September 22, 2014 }}{{cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |title=NASA Craft, Nearing Mars, Prepares to Go to Work |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/22/science/space/nasa-craft-mars.html |date=September 21, 2014 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=September 21, 2014 }}{{cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |title=Probe May Help Solve Riddle of Mars's Missing Air |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/16/science/space/nasa-probe-may-help-solve-riddle-of-marss-missing-air.html |date=November 15, 2013 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=November 15, 2013 }}[http://www.nasa.gov/topics/solarsystem/features/hostile_mars.html New NASA Missions to Investigate How Mars Turned Hostile]. By Bill Steigerwald (November 18, 2012){{cite web|title=Mars Atmosphere and Volatile EvolutioN Mission- Aerospace/Defense |url=https://www.facebook.com/MAVEN2Mars|website=FaceBook|accessdate=28 September 2014}} MAVEN was launched aboard an [[Atlas V]] [[launch vehicle]] at the beginning of the first [[launch window]] on November 18, 2013. Following the first engine burn of the [[Centaur (rocket stage)|Centaur]] second stage, the vehicle coasted in [[low Earth orbit]] for 27 minutes before a second Centaur burn of five minutes to insert it into a [[heliocentric orbit|heliocentric]] Mars [[Hohmann transfer orbit|transit orbit]]. On September 22, 2014, MAVEN reached Mars and was inserted into an [[Areocentric orbit|areocentric]] [[elliptic orbit]] {{convert|6200|km|mi|abbr=on}} by {{convert|150|km|mi|abbr=on}} above the planet's surface. The [[principal investigator]] for the spacecraft is [[Bruce Jakosky]] of the [[Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics]] at the [[University of Colorado Boulder]].{{cite web |last=Hansen |first=Izumi |last2=Zubritsky |first2=Elizabeth |title=NASA Mars Spacecraft Ready for Sept. 21 Orbit Insertion |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?release=2014-314 |date=September 17, 2014 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=September 17, 2014 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/goddard/nasas-maven-spacecraft-makes-final-preparations-for-mars/|title=NASA's MAVEN Spacecraft Makes Final Preparations For Mars|work=NASA}} On November 5, 2015, NASA announced that data from MAVEN shows that the deterioration of Mars' atmosphere increases significantly during [[solar flare|solar storms]]. That loss of atmosphere to space likely played a key role in Mars' gradual shift from its [[carbon dioxide]]-dominated atmosphere – which had kept Mars relatively warm and allowed the planet to support liquid surface water – to the cold, arid planet seen today. This shift took place between about 4.2 and 3.7 billion years ago.{{cite web |last=Northon |first=Karen |title=NASA Mission Reveals Speed of Solar Wind Stripping Martian Atmosphere |url=http://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasa-mission-reveals-speed-of-solar-wind-stripping-martian-atmosphere |date=November 5, 2015 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=November 5, 2015}}{{cite web |last=Wall |first=Mike |title=Mars Lost Atmosphere to Space as Life Took Hold on Earth |url= http://www.space.com/31031-mars-atmosphere-discovery-nasa-maven.html?adbid=662349226177761280&adbpl=tw&adbpr=15431856 |date=November 5, 2015 |work=[[Space.com]] |accessdate=November 6, 2015}} ==History== [[File:MAVEN Launch2-full.jpg|thumb|left|MAVEN – Atlas V ignition (November 18, 2013).]] The mission was spawned by [[NASA]]'s [[Mars Scout Program]], which, although discontinued in 2010, yielded [[Phoenix (spacecraft)|Phoenix]], MAVEN, and numerous missions' studies.{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/NASA-s-Scout-Program-Discontinued-149866.shtml|title=NASA's Scout Program Discontinued|author=Tudor Vieru|date=July 30, 2010|work=softpedia}} Mars Scout missions target a cost of less than US$485 million, not including launch services, which cost approximately $187 million.[http://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2010/oct/HQ_C10-065_Maven_Services.html NASA Awards Launch Services Contract for Maven Mission] (October 21, 2010) The total project costs up to $671 million.{{cite web | url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/09/140919-mars-maven-nasa-space-missions-science-ngspace/ | title=With NASA Probe's Arrival, International Mars Invasion Gets Under Way | work=[[National Geographic Magazine]] | date=19 September 2014 | accessdate=24 September 2014 | author=Vergano, Dan}}{{cite news|title=NASA's Maven Craft Beats India's Mangalyaan in Space Race to Mars|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2014/09/22/nasas-maven-craft-beats-indias-mangalyaan-in-space-race-to-mars/|accessdate=22 September 2014|publisher=WSJ}}{{cite news|title=India Satellite Mangalyaan Reaches Mars Orbit on First Try|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2014/09/24/indias-mangalyaan-enters-mars-orbit/?mod=WSJ_hpp_MIDDLENexttoWhatsNewsForth|accessdate=24 September 2014|publisher=Wall Street Journal}} On September 15, 2008, NASA announced that it had selected MAVEN to be the Mars Scout 2013 mission.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/mars/news/maven_20080915.html|title=NASA – NASA Selects 'MAVEN' Mission to Study Mars Atmosphere|work=NASA}}{{cite news | title = Thumbs Up Given for 2013 NASA Mars Orbiter | date = October 5, 2010 | url = http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.cfm?release=2010-323 | accessdate = October 8, 2010}} There was one other finalist and eight other proposals that were competing against MAVEN. The name is a deliberate use of the word ''[[maven]]'', "a person who has special knowledge or experience; an expert".{{cite web|title=NASA's MAVEN Mission @MAVEN2Mars|url=https://twitter.com/maven2mars/status/394917251918618624|website=Twitter.com|accessdate=7 March 2015|quote=Fittingly, from #Hebrew, via #Yiddish, a "maven" is a trusted expert who understands and seeks to pass knowledge on to others. #MAVEN #Mars}}{{cite book |authorlink1=Houghton Mifflin |title=American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language |date=2000 |publisher=Houghton Mifflin |location=Boston |isbn=0-395-82517-2 |page=1082 |edition=4th |url=https://www.ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=maven |accessdate=7 March 2015 |quote=A person who has special knowledge or experience; an expert.}} On August 2, 2013, the MAVEN spacecraft arrived at [[Kennedy Space Center]] [[Florida]] to begin launch preparations.{{cite web| url= http://www.nasa.gov/press/2013/august/nasa-begins-launch-preparations-for-next-mars-mission/index.html |title=NASA Begins Launch Preparations for Next Mars Mission |accessdate=August 6, 2013 |date=August 5, 2013 |publisher=[[NASA]]}} NASA scheduled the launch of MAVEN from the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]] on November 18, 2013, using an [[Atlas V]] 401 rocket.{{cite web| url= http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=31905 |title=NASA Awards Launch Services Contract for MAVEN Mission | accessdate=October 21, 2010 | publisher=SpaceRef}} The probe arrived in Mars orbit in September 2014, at approximately the same time as India's [[Mars Orbiter Mission]]. On October 1, 2013, only seven weeks before launch, a [[United States federal government shutdown of 2013|government shutdown]] caused suspension of work for two days and initially threatened to force a 26-month postponement of the mission. With the spacecraft nominally scheduled to launch on November 18, a delay beyond December 7 would have caused MAVEN to miss the launch window as [[Mars]] moved too far out of alignment with the [[Earth]].{{cite news|last=Elliott|first=Danielle|title=Government shutdown could delay NASA's Mars MAVEN mission to 2017|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-205_162-57605688/government-shutdown-could-delay-nasas-mars-maven-mission-to-2017/|accessdate=October 3, 2013|newspaper=CBS News|date=October 2, 2013}} However, two days later, a public announcement was made that NASA had deemed the 2013 MAVEN launch so essential to ensuring future communication with current NASA assets on Mars—the [[Opportunity (rover)|Opportunity]] and [[Curiosity rover]]s—that emergency funding was authorized to restart spacecraft processing in preparation for an on-time launch.{{cite web|last=Jakosky |first=Bruce |url=http://lasp.colorado.edu/home/maven/2013/10/03/maven-reactivation-status-update/ |title=MAVEN reactivation status update |publisher=Laboratory of Atmospheric and Space Physics |date=September 20, 2013 |accessdate=October 4, 2013}}{{cite news | first = Richard A. | last = Kerr | title = Shutdown Won't Prevent NASA's MAVEN Mission From Lifting Off | date = October 4, 2013 | url = http://news.sciencemag.org/people-events/2013/10/shutdown-wont-prevent-nasas-maven-mission-lifting | work = Science Magazine | accessdate = October 4, 2013 }} On September 22, 2014, at approximately 2:24 UTC, MAVEN spacecraft entered orbit around Mars, completing an interplanetary journey of 10 months and 442 million miles (711 million kilometers).{{cite news |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/maven/main/ |title=MAVEN Arrives at Mars |work=NASA |date=21 September 2014 |accessdate=2014-09-26 }} [[File:MarsMaven-Orbit-Insertion-142540-20140917.png|thumb |left|400px|alt=Artist concept of the insertion of the MAVEN orbiter around the planet Mars on September 21, 2014.|Artist concept of the insertion of the MAVEN orbiter around the planet Mars on September 21, 2014.]] [[File:Animation of MAVEN trajectory around Mars.gif |500px|thumb |right |Animation of MAVEN{{'s}} trajectory around [[Mars]] from 22 September 2014 to 31 March 2015
{{legend2|magenta| MAVEN}}{{·}}{{legend2| Lime|[[Mars]]}}]] {{clear}} ==Objectives== [[File:Targeting Mars.ogg|thumb|right|200px|alt=MAVEN's interplanetary journey to Mars.|MAVEN's interplanetary journey to Mars.]] Features on Mars that resemble dry [[Stream bed|riverbeds]] and the discovery of minerals that form in the presence of water indicate that Mars once had a [[Atmosphere of Mars|dense enough atmosphere]] and was warm enough for [[Water on Mars|liquid water]] to flow on the surface. However, that thick atmosphere was somehow lost to space. Scientists suspect that over millions of years, Mars lost 99% of its atmosphere as the planet's core cooled and its magnetic field decayed, allowing the [[solar wind]] to sweep away most of the water and volatile compounds that the atmosphere once contained.[http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/maven/news/confirmation.html MAVEN Mission to Investigate How Sun Steals Martian Atmosphere] By Bill Steigerwald (October 5, 2010) The goal of MAVEN is to determine the history of the loss of atmospheric gases to space, providing answers about [[Climate of Mars|Martian climate]] evolution. By measuring the rate with which the atmosphere is currently escaping to space and gathering enough information about the relevant processes, scientists will be able to infer how [[Atmosphere of Mars|the planet's atmosphere]] evolved over time. The MAVEN mission has four primary scientific objectives: [[File:Artist concept of MAVEN spacecraft.jpg|thumb|right|200px|alt=Artist conception of MAVEN spacecraft|Artist conception of MAVEN spacecraft]] #Determine the role that loss of [[volatiles]] to space from the Martian atmosphere has played through time. #Determine the current state of the upper atmosphere, ionosphere, and interactions with the [[solar wind]]. #Determine the current rates of escape of [[Critical ionization velocity|neutral gases]] and [[ion]]s to space and the processes controlling them. #Determine the ratios of stable [[isotope]]s in the Martian atmosphere.[http://lasp.colorado.edu/maven/docs/MAVEN_fact_sheet.pdf MAVEN Fact Sheet] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219191718/http://lasp.colorado.edu/maven/docs/MAVEN_fact_sheet.pdf |date=December 19, 2008 }} MAVEN reached Mars and maneuvered into orbit around the planet on September 21, 2014. The [[Sample Analysis at Mars]] (SAM) instrument suite on board the [[Curiosity rover]] was scheduled to make similar surface measurements from [[Gale crater]] by that date. The data from Curiosity will help guide the interpretation of MAVEN's upper atmosphere measurements. MAVEN's measurements will also provide additional scientific context with which to test models for current [[Atmosphere of Mars#Methane|methane formation in Mars]].{{cite web|url=http://science.discovery.com/stories/mars/questions/questions.html |title=Mars Methane Questions Answered |accessdate=November 14, 2009 |publisher=[[Science (TV channel)|Science channel]] }} == Spacecraft overview == MAVEN was built and tested by [[Lockheed Martin Space Systems]]. Its design is based on those of the [[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]] and [[2001 Mars Odyssey|Mars Odyssey]] spacecraft. The orbiter has a cubical shape of about {{nowrap|2.3 meters × 2.3 meters × 2 meters}} high,[http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/maven/news/maven-structure.html MAVEN Mission Primary Structure Complete]. ''NASA'' (September 26, 2011). with two [[Solar panels on spacecraft|solar arrays]] that hold the magnetometers on both ends. The total length is {{nowrap|11.4 meters}}.[http://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/files/MAVENFactSheet_Final20130610.pdf MAVEN – Facts] ===Relay telecommunications=== [[File:Pia17952 electra transceiver dsc09326 0.jpg|thumb|MAVEN's Electra UHF radio transceiver]] NASA's [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] provided an [[Electra (radio)|Electra]] [[ultra high frequency]] (UHF) relay radio payload{{cite web | url = http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/maven/overview/index.html | title = MAVEN: Answers About Mars Climate History | accessdate = October 25, 2012 | year = 2012 | work = NASA}}[http://www.spaceflight101.com/maven-mission-profile.html MAVEN – Mission Profile]. ''Spaceflight 101''. which has a data return rate of up to {{nowrap|2048 kbit/s}}.{{cite web | url = http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/bitstream/2014/7832/1/03-2150.pdf | title = The Electra Proximity Link Payload for Mars Relay Telecommunications and Navigation | accessdate = January 11, 2013 | date = September 29, 2003 | work = NASA | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130502170707/http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/bitstream/2014/7832/1/03-2150.pdf | archivedate = May 2, 2013 | df = mdy-all }} The highly elliptical orbit of the MAVEN spacecraft may limit its usefulness as a relay for operating landers on the surface, although the long view periods of MAVEN's orbit have afforded some of the largest relay data returns to date of any Mars orbiter.{{cite news |last=Stephen |first=Clark |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/news/n1407/27marstelecom/#.VCHv_Wd0x4s |title=NASA considers commercial telecom satellites at Mars |work=Space Flight Now |date=July 27, 2014 |accessdate=2014-09-23 |quote= It is due to arrive at Mars in September, but MAVEN's planned orbit is not ideal for collecting and sending rover data.}}[http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4370 Newest NASA Mars Orbiter Demonstrates Relay Prowess]. November 10, 2014.{{Cite journal| last=Chamberlain| first=Neil| date=2015-04-07| title=Maven Relay Operations| url= http://2015.aeroconf.org/conference/digest | journal=2015 IEEE Aerospace Conference| doi= |access-date=}} Program item 04.0402 During the mission's first year of operations at Mars — the primary science phase — MAVEN served as a backup relay orbiter. Going forward into the extended mission for a period of up to ten years, MAVEN will provide UHF relay service for present and future Mars rovers and landers.[http://lasp.colorado.edu/home/maven/about/faqs/ MAVEN – FAQ]. NASA. === Scientific instruments === [[File:Main swea5 full.jpg|thumb|Solar Wind Electron Analyzer (SWEA) – measures solar wind and ionosphere electrons.]] [[File:MAVEN — Magnetometer.jpg|thumb|MAVEN's Magnetometer]] [[File:Solar Energetic Particles.jpg|thumb|MAVEN's SEP instrument]] MAVEN will study Mars' upper atmosphere and its interactions with the [[solar wind]]. Its instruments will measure characteristics of Mars' atmospheric gases, upper atmosphere, [[ionosphere]], and the solar wind.{{cite news | author = Jha, Nupur | title = Unique Instrument Devised to Solve Mars' Atmosphere Mystery | date = July 20, 2012 | url = http://www.idigitaltimes.co.uk/articles/492624/20130720/unique-instrument-devised-solve-mars-atmosphere-mystery.htm | work = iDigital Times | accessdate = July 20, 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.vaildaily.com/article/20080915/NEWS/809159935&parentprofile=search|title=CU chosen for $485M Mars exploration project|work=The VailDaily|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011201755/http://www.vaildaily.com/article/20080915/NEWS/809159935%26parentprofile%3Dsearch|archivedate=October 11, 2008|df=mdy-all}} MAVEN will perform measurements from a highly elliptical orbit over a period of one Earth year, with five "deep dips" at {{convert|150|km|mi|abbr=on}} minimum altitude to sample the upper atmosphere.[http://lasp.colorado.edu/home/maven/about/mission-timeline/ Mission Timeline]. University of Colorado Boulder. The [[University of Colorado Boulder]], [[University of California, Berkeley]], and [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] each built a suite of instruments for the spacecraft, and they include:{{cite web | url = http://lasp.colorado.edu/home/maven/science/instrument-package/ | title = MAVEN – Instruments | accessdate = October 25, 2012 | year = 2012 | work = University of Colorado Boulder}} Built by the University of California, Berkeley [[Space Sciences Laboratory]]: * Solar Wind Electron Analyzer (SWEA) – measures [[solar wind]] and ionosphere electrons * Solar Wind Ion Analyzer (SWIA) – measures solar wind and [[magnetosheath]] ion density and velocity * SupraThermal And Thermal Ion Composition (STATIC) – measures thermal ions to moderate-energy escaping ions * Solar Energetic Particle (SEP) – determines the impact of [[Solar energetic particles|SEPs]] on the upper atmosphere Built by the University of Colorado [[Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics]]: * Imaging Ultraviolet Spectrometer (IUVS) – measures global characteristics of the upper atmosphere and ionosphere * Langmuir Probe and Waves (LPW) – determines ionosphere properties and wave heating of escaping ions and solar [[extreme ultraviolet]] (EUV) input to atmosphere Built by Goddard Space Flight Center: * Magnetometer (MAG) – measures interplanetary solar wind and ionosphere [[Magnetosphere|magnetic fields]]{{Cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/maven/news/magnetometers.html |title=NASA Goddard Delivers Magnetometers for NASA's Next Mission to Mars |publisher=NASA |first=Nancy |last=Neal-Jones |date=May 21, 2012}} * Neutral Gas and Ion Mass Spectrometer (NGIMS) - measures the composition and [[isotope]]s of [[Critical ionization velocity|neutral gases]] and [[ion]]s SWEA, SWIA, STATIC, SEP, LPW, and MAG are part of the Particles and Fields instrument suite, IUVS is the Remote Sensing instrument suite, and NGIMS is its own eponymous suite. ==Status== The orbiter is in Mars orbit and operational. The commissioning phase lasted until the first week of November 2014 (six weeks), and then the science phase of the mission commenced.{{cite news |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/09/140922111111.htm |title=NASA's Newest Mars Mission Spacecraft Enters Orbit around Red Planet |work=Science Daily |date=22 September 2014 |accessdate=2014-09-24 }} In June 2015, the science phase was extended through September 2016.{{cite web |url=http://lasp.colorado.edu/home/maven/about/faqs/ |title=MAVEN – FAQ |work=University of Colorado |accessdate=2016-04-06 }} MAVEN carries enough fuel to extend its science mission for an additional two years, and then another six years to function as a telecomm orbiter at a higher, more circular orbit. In March 2017 MAVEN's orbit had to be changed slightly because it had a high probability of colliding with Phobos within one week.{{Cite news|url=http://spacenews.com/nasa-spacecraft-avoids-potential-collision-with-martian-moon/|title=NASA spacecraft avoids potential collision with Martian moon - SpaceNews.com|date=2017-03-03|work=SpaceNews.com|access-date=2017-12-31|language=en-US}} Since the [[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]] (MRO) is starting to fail and development of the [[Next Mars Orbiter]] for communications relay was postponed to the late 2020s,{{cite news |url=https://spaceflightnow.com/2018/04/09/nasa-is-counting-on-long-lived-mars-orbiter-lasting-another-decade/ |title=NASA is counting on long-lived Mars orbiter lasting another decade |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=April 9, 2018 |accessdate=April 22, 2018}} NASA is moving ahead with plans to alter the orbit of MAVEN to have it serve as a communications relay.[http://spacenews.com/nasa-mars-exploration-efforts-turn-to-operating-existing-missions-and-planning-sample-return/ NASA Mars exploration efforts turn to operating existing missions and planning sample return]. Jeff Foust, ''Space News''. 23 February 2018. It will be lowered to 4,000 to 4,500 kilometers altitude, where it can serve as a relay while continuing its science mission. ==Results== Data from the MAVEN orbiter published in 2015 confirmed that the [[solar wind]] is responsible for stripping away the [[atmosphere of Mars]] over the years, as the shielding effect of the global magnetic field was lost as the planet's internal dynamo cooled.{{cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |title=Solar Storms Strip Air From Mars, NASA Says |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/06/science/space/mars-atmosphere-stripped-away-by-solar-storms-nasa-says.html |date=November 5, 2015 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=November 5, 2015 }}{{cite web |author=Staff |title=VIDEO (51:58) – MAVEN – Measuring Mars' Atmospheric Loss |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y4vVFetfSF8 |date=November 5, 2015 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=November 5, 2015 }} {{wide image|PIA18613-MarsMAVEN-Atmosphere-3UV-Views-20141014.jpg|600px|align-cap=center|Mars – [[Atmosphere of Mars|escaping atmosphere]] – [[carbon]], [[oxygen]], [[hydrogen]] (MAVEN; [[Ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy|UV]]; October 14, 2014).{{cite web |last=Jones |first=Nancy |last2=Steigerwald |first2=Bill |last3=Brown |first3=Dwayne |last4=Webster |first4=Guy |title=NASA Mission Provides Its First Look at Martian Upper Atmosphere |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?release=2014-351 |date=October 14, 2014 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=October 15, 2014 }}}} Mars loses water into its thin atmosphere by evaporation. There, solar radiation can split the water molecules into their components, hydrogen and oxygen. The hydrogen, as the lightest element, then tends to rise far up to the highest levels of the Martian atmosphere, where several processes can strip it away into space, to be forever lost to the planet. This loss was thought to proceed at a fairly constant rate, but MAVEN's observations of Mars's atmospheric hydrogen through a full Martian year (almost two Earth years) show that the escape rate is highest when Mars's orbit brings it closest to the Sun, and only one-tenth as great when it is at its farthest.{{cite web |last= |first= |date=2016-10-22 |title=NASA's MAVEN Mission Observes Ups and Downs of Water Escape from Mars |url= http://www.astrobio.net/also-in-news/nasas-maven-mission-observes-ups-downs-water-escape-mars/ |work= Astrobiology Magazine |location= |access-date= 2016-10-23 | quote= }}{{cite web |last=Ang |first=Brian |date=2016-10-21 |title=NASA: MAVEN mission probes 'water-escaping' occurrences on Mars |url= http://www.hngn.com/amp/articles/212920/20161021/nasa-s-maven-mission-probes-mars-water-spilling-space-puzzle.htm |work=HNGN |location= |access-date= 2016-10-23 | quote= }} In September 2017, NASA reported [[Radiation|radiation levels]] on the surface of the planet [[Mars]] were temporarily [[Orders of magnitude (radiation)|doubled]], and were associated with an [[aurora]] 25 times brighter than any observed earlier, due to a massive, and unexpected, [[Coronal mass ejection|solar storm]] in the middle of the month.{{cite web |last=Scott |first=Jim |title=Large solar storm sparks global aurora and doubles radiation levels on the martian surface |url=https://phys.org/news/2017-09-large-solar-storm-global-aurora.html |date=September 30, 2017 |work=[[Phys.org]] |accessdate=September 30, 2017 }} ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Atmosphere of Mars]] * [[ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter]] * [[Exploration of Mars]] * [[List of Mars orbiters]] * [[List of missions to Mars]] * [[Mars Express]] * [[Mars Global Surveyor]] * [[Mars MetNet]] * [[Mars Next Generation]] (a proposed orbiter) * [[Mars Orbiter Mission]] * [[New Frontiers program]] * [[Sandra Cauffman]] * [[Space weather]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Wiktionary|Maven}} {{Commons}} *[http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/maven/main/index.html MAVEN – NASA] *[http://mars.jpl.nasa.gov/programmissions/missions/present/maven/ MAVEN – JPL] *[http://lasp.colorado.edu/home/maven/ MAVEN – University of Colorado Boulder] *[http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/maven/news/propellant-tank.html Integration of MAVEN Propellant Tank – NASA] *[http://www.spaceflightnow.com/mars/maven/status.html SpaceflightNow MAVEN mission status center] *[http://lasp.colorado.edu/home/maven/science/released-results/ Released results from MAVEN] {{Mars spacecraft}} {{Solar System probes}} {{NASA navbox}} {{Orbital launches in 2013}} satellites and probes]] [[Category:Mars Scout Program]] [[Category:Missions to Mars]] [[Category:NASA space probes]] [[Category:Space probes launched in 2013]] [[Category:Articles containing video [[File:The Maiden Paps - geograph.org.uk - 511481.jpg|thumb|The Maiden Paps near [[Hawick]].]] [[File:Maidens Paps - geograph.org.uk - 855062.jpg|thumb|Maidens Paps cairn in the [[Kilpatrick Hills]].]]
'''Maiden Paps''', '''Maidens Paps''' or '''Maiden's Pap''' may refer to: *Maidens Paps, a cairn near Cochno Loch in the [[Kilpatrick Hills]], Scotland *[[Maiden Paps, Hawick]], twin hills, 510 m and 500 m, south of Hawick in the Scottish Borders, Scotland *[[Tunstall Hills]], Sunderland, Tyne and Wear, England *[[Maiden Paps, Caithness]], a 430 m hill in Caithness, Scotland *[[Schiehallion]], 1083 m, Schiehallion, Perth and Kinross, Scotland * [[Maiden Paps, North Carolina]] a historical island in North Carolina, United States
==See also== * [[Paps of Anu]] * [[Pap of Glencoe]] * [[Paps of Jura]] * [[Breast-shaped hill]]

{{about| the protected area in South Australia|the associated wetland system | Coongie Lakes}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date= January 2015}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = protected | name = Malkumba-Coongie Lakes National Park | state = sa | iucn_category = ii | image = | caption = | image_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|27|15|41|S|140|9|25|E|display=inline,title}} | force_national_map = | relief = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | map_alt = | nearest_town_or_city = [[Innamincka, South Australia|Innamincka]] | area = 266.69 | area_footnotes = {{cite web|title=Protected Areas Information System - reserve list (as of 25 November 2014)|url=http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/b88e6e26-4bd9-4c68-8fff-9e800114eb69/park-management-protected-areas-gen.pdf|publisher=Department of Environment Water and Natural Resources|accessdate=8 January 2015|pages=}} | established = 22 December 1988 | established_footnotes = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_footnotes = | managing_authorities = [[Department of Environment and Water (South Australia)|DEW]],
Yandruwandha Yawarrawarrka Parks Advisory Committee,
South Australian Arid Lands Natural Resources Management Board. | url = http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/parks/Find_a_Park/Browse_by_region/Flinders_Ranges_and_Outback/Malkumba-Coongie_Lakes_National_Park }} '''Malkumba-Coongie Lakes National Park''' is a [[protected area]] located in the north-east of [[South Australia]] about {{convert|110|km|abbr=off}} north-west of [[Innamincka, South Australia|Innamincka]]. The national park was proclaimed on 31 March 2005 as the Coongie Lakes National Park under ''[[National Parks and Wildlife Act 1972]]'' over a parcel of land previously part of the [[Innamincka Regional Reserve]] to "conserve significant wetlands, provide experiences for visitors and ensure that the core component of the Coongie Lakes system was protected." The national park is located on land that was included on the [[List of Wetlands of International Importance]] under the [[Ramsar Convention]] under the name, [[Coongie Lakes]] in 1987. In 2014, the national park was renamed as the Malkumba-Coongie Lakes National Park. The national park is co-managed by the [[Department of Environment and Water (South Australia)|Department of Environment and Water]] (DEW), the Yandruwandha Yawarrawarrka Parks Advisory Committee and South Australian Arid Lands Natural Resources Management Board. It is classified as an [[International Union for Conservation of Nature|IUCN]] [[IUCN protected area categories#Category II — National Park|Category II protected area]].{{Gazetteer of Australia|name= Coongie Lakes National Park|feature= SA0016973}}{{cite web|title= Malkumba-Coongie Lakes National Park Management Plan 2014 |url= http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/ade01b4c-5dcb-4a5c-b261-a41900bf0b40/malkumba-coongie-lakes-management-plan.pdf|publisher= Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources |accessdate=15 January 2015|date= 2014|pages =2,4&9}}{{cite web|title= Coongie Lakes Ramsar wetlands; a plan for wise use |url= http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/ca6cccb1-b4d2-4529-9cc7-9e3100cab00c/coongie.pdf |publisher= Department of Environment, Heritage & Aboriginal Affairs|accessdate=15 January 2015|date= 1999|page = 2}}{{cite web|title=New name for the Coongie Lakes National Park|url=http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/92fe6dbd-94de-45ec-bf71-a38e01174861/140807-coongie-lakes-name-change-nws.pdf|publisher=Government of South Australia|accessdate=16 January 2015}}{{cite web|title= Terrestrial Protected Areas of South Australia (see 'DETAIL' tab)|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/system/files/pages/0f927a4e-336a-490c-a896-ec37874a5c73/files/capad2012sa.xlsx|work=CAPAD 2012|publisher=Australian Government - Department of the Environment|accessdate=6 February 2014|date=6 February 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/parks/Find_a_Park/Browse_by_region/Flinders_Ranges_and_Outback/Malkumba-Coongie_Lakes_National_Park Malkumba-Coongie Lakes National Park official webpage] *[http://www.protectedplanet.net/coongie-lakes-national-park Malkumba-Coongie Lakes National Park webpage on protected planet] {{Protected areas of South Australia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Malkumba-Coongie Lakes National Park}} [[Category:National parks of South Australia]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 2005]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Far North (South Australia)]] {{SouthAustralia-protected-area-stub}} {{Protected-area-stub}}
